newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania plans Tarom restructure despite protests.
newsitem.headline: Romania plans Tarom restructure despite protests.

text.p: Romania's main privatisation agency vowed on Wednesday to proceed with plans to restructure the national airline Tarom despite a threatened strike by maintenance staff which could ground its flights.

"We are working on a restructuring plan for Tarom with very tough measures, which is absolutely vital if we want Romania to continue to have a national carrier," said Sorin Dimitriu, head of the State Ownership Fund (FPS).
"No sentimental reason or trade union action will be allowed in our restructuring plan," he told a news conference.

Several hundred mechanics and engineers gathered for the third consecutive day at Tarom's maintenance centre outside Bucharest's Otopeni airport to denounce a plan for 1,000 temporary layoffs to cut wage bills.
Flights have so far been unaffected, but staff have threatened to halt maintenance checks and shut down the airline's operations unless the plan is withdrawn.
Dimitriu said Tarom needed to cut jobs, withdraw ageing aircraft and improve efficiency after years of bad management.
He said the FPS, Tarom's majority shareholder, was considering turning over the airline's management to an international company, but declined to give details.

Tarom has laboured under huge debts in recent years, compounded by high fees to air traffic control and airport authorities. Trade unions want maintained state subsidies, early retirement packages instead of layoffs and have asked the airline to shed loss-making subcontractors.

A restructuring plan to compete in growing east European markets was initiated in 1995. But it stalled under leftists who held power after the ousting of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in 1989 until their election defeat last year.
The carrier plans to buy eight new Boeing 737s as part of a project to upgrade its fleet.
